channel.title: Projects on Paul Schumacher
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Paul Schumacher

item.title: CountVectorizer, LightFM, and RelationalAI’s Snowflake Native App: Recommender systems applying WARP and Cosine Similarity
item.description: For a private project, I researched the state-of-the-art recommender systems (RecSys). These algorithms are designed to suggest items to users based on factors such as similarity between users (User-based Collaborative Filtering), similarity between items (Item-based Collaborative Filtering), the content of items, and user preferences (Content-Based Filtering), or a combination of these methods (Hybrid Methods). In this article, I explore CountVectorization, the LightFM library, and the RelationalAI’s Snowflake Native App. I apply Weighted Approximate-Rank Pairwise (WARP) loss function and Cosine Similarity to address real-world challenges and provide their solutions.

item.title: Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM): FY2024 Analysis of an S&P 500 Fashion Company
item.description: As a data science intern at Ekimetrics, I collaborated with three analysts from the company's London office to conduct an in-depth analysis of the performance of a leading S&P 500 company in the UK fashion industry. Our analysis focused on evaluating both short-term and long-term media return on investment, assessing the brand halo impact of luxury campaigns across various channels, and measuring the media memory impact on current transactions. We also reported the contributions of different media channels by campaign type, such as lifestyle and commerce, and evaluated the impact of events, sponsorships, and celebrity endorsements on both short-term and long-term business performance.

item.title: Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM): Q3 2023 Analysis of a S&P 500 Health Care Company
item.description: As a data science intern at Ekimetrics, I, along with four other analysts, conducted an in-depth analysis of the performance of a leading S&P 500 company in the electrolyte drinks market in the US. This study covered a three-year period up to September 30, 2023. Our comprehensive analysis focused on comparing the latest 52-week period with the same period in 2022, offering valuable insights into market dynamics and strategic outcomes.

item.title: Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM) and Match Market Testing (MMT): FY2024 Analysis for a S&P 500 Cosmetique Company
item.description: This project marked my debut as a data science intern at Ekimetrics in New York. Our team of three analysts meticulously examined the entire US operations of an S&P 500 cosmetics company. We focused on the period from January 2023 to December 2023, analyzing data across three key channels: Brand.com, Retailer.com, and Brick & Mortar (B&M). Throughout the project, we processed a substantial 10.5 gigabytes of data.

item.title: Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM): Comparing Bayesian Modeling using PyMC3 vs. Random Forest Modeling with SHAP Evaluation
item.description: In this article, I explore two different advanced Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM) approaches and compare the results obtained from the Bayesian approach with those from the Random Forest approach. The Random Forest approach, which captures non-linear relationships and interactions more effectively, outperforms the Bayesian approach, showing significant improvements in performance metrics, with a 40% reduction in MAPE and a 17% decrease in NRMSE.

item.title: ARIMA, Prophet, XGBoost: Retail Store Sales Forecast
item.description: In this comprehensive analysis, I delve into the intricate world of sales forecasting for Rossmann, a retail giant operating across seven European countries. Understanding and predicting the company's daily sales is a pivotal challenge, as it involves a myriad of factors, including promotions, competition, holidays, seasonality, and local trends. The Predictive Modeling covers ARIMA, Meta's Prophet, and the open-source software library XGBoost.

item.title: Dashboard Visualization with SQL & Tableau: Regional Flu Vaccinations, Emergency Room Visits, and COVID-19 Distribution
item.description: For these projects, I managed 39.7 MB of healthcare data in SQL and visualized the results in three Tableau dashboards. In the first dashboard, I presented the annual flu vaccination rates in counties in Massachusetts for 2022. In the second, I displayed an emergency room visits dashboard based on fictional data. In the third, I showcased the geographical distribution of COVID-19 globally as of October 2023.

item.title: Google's Lightweight Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM): Bike Store Advertisement Revenue Analysis
item.description: In this project, I undertook a comprehensive analysis of a bicycle store's Return on Investment (ROI) across a range of advertising strategies. Spanning five years, the store employed a deliberate approach by leveraging seven distinct marketing channels, which included both branded and non-branded search, Facebook, print, out-of-home advertising (OOH), television (TV), and radio.

item.title: HTML, CSS, JavaScript: Developing a Real Time Clock, a Random Password Generator, and a To-Do List
item.description: I developed these three applications to strengthen my skillset in web design using HyperText Markup Language (HTML), Cascading Style Sheets (CSS), and JavaScript (JS). The clock displays the current Pacific Standard Time, while the random password generator and the to-do list are integrated into the portfolio using CodePen. I'm excited to showcase these projects as they represent my commitment to creating practical and engaging web applications. Feel free to explore and interact with them!

item.title: Two-Stage Least-Squares regression with Composition Adjustment: The China Shock and Regional Gender Pay Gaps in the United States
item.description: This project served as my final thesis and capstone project for the Master of Quantitative Economics program at UCLA, submitted during the spring quarter of 2023. The project was under the supervision of Professor Jonathan Vogel. If you’re interested in reading the entire paper, you can download my thesis here. The project aimed to assess the impact of the rise in imported goods from the People’s Republic of China on the United States of America with a focus on their inherent gender pay gap.

item.title: Data Visualisation: The Change in Value of the Associate’s Degree after the 2007/2008 Financial Crisis
item.description: This group project was conducted for the course on Income Inequality instructed by Professor Jonathan Vogel in the Master of Quantitative Economics program at UCLA. The corresponding presentation slide deck can be downloaded. We explored the question of how the share of people owning an Associate’s Degree and the wage differences compared to other degrees evolved after the Great Financial Crisis (GFC) of 2007/2008. The underlying theory, supported by empirical research, suggests that as the unemployment rate increases, college enrollment rates also tend to rise (Long, 2004b).

item.title: Image and Video Generation using Stable Diffusion
item.description: This group project was a contribution to the Data Science Union. We viewed it as an exploratory journey into the field of image creation with ‘Dalleshop,’ a word combining ‘Dall-e’ and ‘Photoshop.’ Our inspiration stemmed from the work of Omar Sanseviero and Santiago. The basic idea of picture creation is simple: you first give a model some noise, in other words, millions and millions of pictures, to generate an image through a neural network.

item.title: Random Forest in Machine Learning: Predict Match Winners in the German Soccer League Bundesliga
item.description: In this project, which I undertook as part of the UCLA Data Science Union, I focused on predicting the outcome of the final matches of the 2022/2023 season in the German Soccer League Bundesliga. During the data collection phase, I gathered information from the FBRef website, covering a total of 24 out of the 34 matches that had been played up to that point. The aim of the project was to leverage data analysis and predictive modeling to anticipate the results of the remaining matches in the season’s final stage.

item.title: Natural Language Processing: Top2Vec, LDA, LSA
item.description: This project highlights my involvement in the “Twitch Twits” program for the Data Science Union student association at UCLA. The dataset was meticulously collected from the Twitch API. By utilizing the “rTwitchAPI” package in the R programming language, I conducted web scraping to gather data pertaining to one of the most frequently featured games on the Twitch streaming platform: Alien Isolation. The dataset comprised 871 distinct streaming titles. Initially, I partitioned the data into separate train and test sets.
